body:
>that's exactly why there has to be a standard form of a language that everyone's taught.

Not really, so long there's a way to infer meaning from context (or a quick google search). This is almost the worst case scenario for language mutation:

https://www.bbc.com/pidgin

yet it's still (mostly) understandable.

>for example, when i say "i'm quite sure about something" people don't think that i mean "i'm not sure" the way they always do, now that "quite" doesn't mean what it means.

Who uses "quite" to mean "not really"?

body:
> And anyone that worship the satanic triad-idol and a human being as God is too.

I agree that the Romans corrupted it, but that is not one of the things they did. While it is true that earlier bibles omit some references to the trinity, many others are not. Even in the old testament it's described. And besides, why would they bother doing that? It wouldn't help them further their agenda, so that'd be a rather silly thing to change. More suspicious are statements made randomly smack in the middle of other passages that just so happen to justify the beliefs of the Roman Empire, like 1 Corinthians 13:34-35.
